utterance: "I'M IN COMMAND,"
speaker: the gentleman

utterance: "Gentlemen, marsters, don't teck my horses, ef you please,"
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: "Look! Look! They are running. They are beating our men!"
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: bet they didn't have any general who could beat Joab.
speaker: Willy

utterance: "Ef them Britishers jest sees dese swodes dee'll run!"
speaker: Old Uncle Billy

utterance: "There they are,"
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: "No, that is a picket,"
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: "gallop on, Frank, and tell them we are bringing breakfast for the regiment."
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: "Halt! Where are you going in such a hurry, my young man?"
speaker: a soldier

utterance: "I wish to see the colonel,"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "What do you want with him?"
speaker: a soldier

utterance: "There he is,"
speaker: a soldier

utterance: "Where?"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "There,"
speaker: a soldier

utterance: "Hullo, bud, going to jine the cavalry?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Which is oldest; you or your horse?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Does your mother know you're out?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "How's pa-and ma?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Are there any Yankees around, that you were running away so fast just now?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "No; if there were I'd never have found you here,"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "I wish to see Colonel Marshall,"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "All right, sir, I'm the man,"
speaker: Colonel Marshall

utterance: "You the colonel!"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Yes, I'm the lieutenant-colonel. I'm in command,"
speaker: Colonel Marshall

utterance: "Won't you get down? Here, Campbell, take this horse, will you?"
speaker: Colonel Marshall

utterance: "Now, come with me,"
speaker: Colonel Marshall

utterance: "We must get ready to receive your mother."
speaker: Colonel Marshall

utterance: "There are some ladies coming-and breakfast,"
speaker: Colonel Marshall

utterance: "Now let us go and receive your mother,"
speaker: Colonel Marshall

utterance: "What's the matter with you? Go and lie down, Bruno,"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Hush up, Nick!"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Willy-Willy, wake up; there's some one moving around outdoors."
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Umm-mm,"
speaker: Willy

utterance: "Wake up, Willy!"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "There's some one at the hen-house."
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Let's go and wake Uncle Balla,"
speaker: Willy

utterance: "No; I'll tell you what, let's catch him ourselves,"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "All right,"
speaker: Willy

utterance: "We'll catch him and lock him up; suppose he's got a pistol? your gun maybe won't go off; it doesn't always burst the cap."
speaker: Willy

utterance: "Well, your old musket is loaded, and you can hold him, while I snap the cap at him, and get it ready."
speaker: Frank

utterance: "All right-I can't find my jacket-I'll hold him."
speaker: Willy

utterance: "Where in the world is my hat?"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Never mind, it must be in the house. Let's go out the back way. We can get out without his hearing us."
speaker: Willy

utterance: "What shall we do with the dogs? Let's shut them up."
speaker: Frank

utterance: "No, let's take 'em with us. We can keep them quiet and hold 'em in, and they can track him if he gets away."
speaker: Willy

utterance: "All right;"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "There he goes round the garden,"
speaker: Willy

utterance: "Come on,"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Here's one, Willy,"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Willy, you take good aim at him, and if he pokes his head out-let him have it!"
speaker: Frank

utterance: "Willy, is that
speaker: the prisoner

utterance: Balla, come here.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Balla, I want you to know that if you wish to go, you can do so.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Hi, Mistis-
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I want you all to know it.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: I want you all to know it-every one on the place! You can go if you wish; but, if you go, you can never come back!
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Hi, Mistis, whar is I got to go? I wuz born on dis place an' I 'spec' to die here, an' be buried right yonder.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Dat I does. Y'all sticks by us, and we'll stick by you.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I know I ain't gwine nowhar wid no Yankees or nothin'.
speaker: Lucy Ann

utterance: Dee tell me dee got hoofs and horns.
speaker: one of the women in the yard

utterance: Where is it, Balla? What is it?
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: It's the depot, madam. They's burnin' it. That man told me they was burnin' ev'ywhar they went.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Will they be here to-night?
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: No, marm; I don' hardly think they will. That man said they couldn't travel more than thirty miles a day; but they'll be plenty of 'em here to-morrow-to breakfast.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Here, you all come here.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Go in there and get down the bacon-take a piece, each of you.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Balla, step here.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Yes'm, that's so; that's jes' what I wuz gwine do.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Frank, you and Willy go and tell Balla to come to the chamber door. He may be out in the stable.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Balla, come in here.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Have you got them safe?
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Yes'm; jes' as safe as they kin be. I want to be 'bout here when they come, or I'd go down an' stay whar they is.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: What is it?
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: Where is the best place to put that?
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Well, I declar', Mistis, that's hard to tell, without it's in the stable.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: They may burn that down.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: That's so; you might bury it under the floor of the smoke-house?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I have heard that they always look for silver there. How would it do to bury it in the garden?
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: That's the very place I was gwine name. They can't burn that down, and if they gwine dig for it then they'll have to dig a long time before they git over that big garden.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I thought of the other end of the flower-bed, between the big rose-bush and the lilac.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: That's the very place I had in my mind. They won' never fine it dyah!
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: We know a good place; it's a heap better than that. It's where we bury our treasures when we play 'Black-beard the Pirate.'
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: Very well; I don't care to know where it is until after to-morrow, anyhow. I know I can trust you.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Yes'm, you know dat.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I'll jes' go an' git my hoe.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: The garden hasn't got a roof to it, has it, Unc' Balla?
speaker: Willy

utterance: Go 'way from here, boy. That boy ain' never done talkin' 'bout that thing yit.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: And you ain't ever given me all those chickens either.
speaker: Willy

utterance: Oh, well, I'm gwi' do it; ain't you hear me say I'm gwine do it?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: That's the way we always do when we bury the treasure. Ain't it, Willy?
speaker: Frank

utterance: If a man speaks, it's death!
speaker: Willy

utterance: Give the ‘galleon’ to us.
speaker: Frank

utterance: No; be off with you.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: That ain't the way. A pirate never digs the hole until he has his treasure at hand. To do so would prove him but a novice; wouldn't it, Willy?
speaker: Frank

utterance: Well, I leave it all to you, my little Buccaneers. I'll take care of the spoons and forks we use every day. I'll just hide them away in a hole somewhere.
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Look here, boys; I ain' got time to fool with you chillern. Ain't you hear your ma tell me she 'pend on me to bury that silver what yo' gran'ma and gran'pa used to eat off o'-an' don' wan' nobody to know nothin' 'bout it? An' y' all comin' here with guns, like you huntin' squ'rr'ls, an' now talkin' 'bout wadin' in the ditch!
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: But, Unc' Balla, that's the way all buccaneers do.
speaker: Frank

utterance: Yes, buccaneers always go by water.
speaker: Willy

utterance: And we can stoop in the ditch and come in at the far end of the garden, so nobody can see us.
speaker: Frank

utterance: Bookanear or bookafar,—I's gwine in dat garden and dig a hole wid my hoe, an' I is too ole to be wadin' in a ditch like chillern. I got the misery in my knee now, so bad I'se sca'cely able to stand. I don't know huccome y' all ain't satisfied with the place you' ma an' I done pick, anyways.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Here is the spot.
speaker: Frank

utterance: It's in a line with the longest limb of the big oak-tree by the gate, and when this locust bush and that cedar grow to be big trees, it will be just half-way between them.
speaker: Willy

utterance: It's a first-rate place! Ain't it, Unc' Balla?
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: Do you think it will do, Balla?
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Oh, yes, madam; it's far enough, an' they got mighty comical ways to get dyah, wadin' in ditch an' things—it will do. I ain' sho' I kin fin' it ag'in myself.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Unc' Balla, where are your horses?
speaker: Frank or Willy

utterance: That's for me to know, an' them to find out what kin.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Get up, you lazy little rebels.
speaker: one of the intruders

utterance: Leave the room instantly! Aren't you ashamed to frighten children!
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: We haven't hurt the brats.
speaker: the man with the sword

utterance: Well, you terrify them to death. It's just as bad. Give me those clothes!
speaker: Mrs. Han

utterance: Old man, come here!
speaker: some of them

utterance: Who?-me?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: B'ain't you the carriage driver?
speaker: some of them

utterance: Ain't I the keridge driver?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Yes, you; we know you are, so you need not be lying about it.
speaker: some of them

utterance: Hi! yes; I the keridge driver. Who say I ain't?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Well, where have you hid those horses? Come, we want to know, quick.
speaker: the fellow

utterance: Here, you come with us. We won't have no foolin' 'bout this. If you don't show us pretty quick where those horses are, we'll put a bullet or two into you. March off there!
speaker: the fellow

utterance: Hi! Marster, don't pint dat thing at me that way. I ain't ready to die yit-an' I ain' like dem things, noways.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Hi! there are Bill and John, now.
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: Well, ef dee ain't got 'em, sho' 'nough!
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Gentlemen, marsters, don't teck my horses, ef you please.
speaker: Uncle Balla
addressee: the man who led the horses

utterance: I wish Marse William could see you ridin' 'cross them fields.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: What is it?
speaker: Frank

utterance: 'Tain't anything but some cows or sheep, I believe.
speaker: Willy

utterance: Frank! Frank!
speaker: Willy

utterance: What?
speaker: Frank

utterance: It's the old spotted sow, and she's got a lot of pigs with her great big shoats, nearly grown!
speaker: Willy

utterance: At least six of 'em!
speaker: Frank

utterance: Let's follow 'em!
speaker: Frank

utterance: All right.
speaker: Willy

utterance: Let's shoot 'em.
speaker: Frank

utterance: All right.
speaker: Willy

utterance: It's like hunting wild boars, isn't it?
speaker: Willy

utterance: Let's go home.
speaker: Willy

utterance: 'Tain't any use to try to get through there. My legs are scratched all to pieces now.
speaker: Willy

utterance: Let's try and get out here.
speaker: Frank

utterance: How am I to get the gun across?
speaker: Willy

utterance: That's a fact! It's too far to throw it, even with the caps off.
speaker: Frank

utterance: There they go, there they go!
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: There's where they go in and out.
speaker: Frank

utterance: I wish we had let Peter and Cole come.
speaker: Willy

utterance: Or had asked Uncle Balla to help us.
speaker: Frank

utterance: They'd be certain to tell all about it.
speaker: Frank

utterance: Yes; so they would.
speaker: Willy

utterance: I tell you what we ought to do! Bait the hog-path, as you would for fish.
speaker: Frank

utterance: With what?
speaker: Willy

utterance: Acorns.
speaker: Frank

utterance: Look there, Willy!
speaker: Frank

Goodness! Why, here are the General and Hugh!
How in the world did you get away?

speaker: the youngsters

utterance: Where? How many? What are they doing?
speaker: the General

utterance: A whole pack of 'em-right up there at the stables, and all about, feeding their horses and sitting all around, and ever so many more have gone along down the road.
speaker: the youngsters

utterance: Fling the fence down there!
speaker: the boys

utterance: Let's go and see the fight!
speaker: the boys

utterance: S'pose they shoot! Won't they shoot us?

utterance: We can lie flat and peep over the top of the hill.
speaker: Frank

utterance: Let's go around that way.
speaker: Frank

utterance: Look at Hugh! Look at Hugh!

utterance: Look! That horse has fallen down!

utterance: He's shot!
speaker: Frank

utterance: See; they are running!

utterance: Come on!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Look! look! They are running-they are beating our men!

utterance: They have driven 'em back across the bridge!

utterance:
What shall we do?
Suppose they see us!

utterance: Come on, Mah'srs Frank 'n' Willy, let's go home,
speaker: the colored boys

utterance: They'll shoot us.
speaker: the colored boys

utterance: What's them things 'zip-zippin' 'round my ears?

utterance: Bullets
speaker: Frank

utterance: Will they hurt me if they hit me?
speaker: one of the negro boys

utterance: Of course they will. They'll kill you.
speaker: Frank

utterance: I'm gwine home
speaker: the boy

utterance: Hold on!—We're goin', too; but let's go down this way; this is the best way.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: What in the name of goodness are you boys doing here?
speaker: a soldier

utterance: We're just looking on an' lis'ning
speaker: the boys

utterance: Well, you'd better be getting home as fast as you can. They are too strong for us, and they'll be driving us back directly, and some of you may get killed or run over.
speaker: a soldier

utterance: Come on! Let's go home!

utterance: Water!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Oh, for some water!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: What's that?

No.

utterance: Willy, it's my Yankee!

utterance: Frank, it's getting mighty late, and we've got to go home

utterance: Willy, let's say our prayers for him

speaker: the soldier

speaker: the lips

speaker: Willy

utterance: God bless
speaker: the lips

utterance: He's dead
speaker: Frank

utterance: Frank, aren't you mighty sorry?
speaker: Willy

utterance: I don't want him to die! I don't want him to die!
speaker: Willy

utterance: Take off the saddles, Ralph, and turn the horses out,
speaker: the boys' father

utterance: Here, here's my last dollar. You have been a faithful servant to me. Put the saddles on the porch.
speaker: the boys' father

utterance: You are free
speaker: the boys' father

utterance: Little boys!
speaker: the lady

utterance: We are looking for my son; and this gentleman tells me that you live about here, and know more of the country than any one else I may meet.
speaker: the lady

utterance: Do you know where any graves is?-Yankee graves?
speaker: the driver

utterance: Yes, there are several down on the road by Pigeon Hill, where the battle was, and two or three by the creek down yonder, and there's one in our garden.
speaker: the boys

utterance: Where was your son killed, ma'am? Do you know that he was killed?
speaker: the driver

utterance: I do not know. We fear that he was; but, of course, we still hope there may have been some mistake. The last seen of him was when General Sheridan went through this country, last year. He was with his company in the rear-guard, and was wounded and left on the field. We hoped he might have been found in one of the prisons; but there is no trace of him, and we fear-
speaker: the lady

utterance: He was my only son, my only son—and I gave him up for the Union, and-
speaker: the lady

utterance: If I could but find his grave. Even that would be better than this agonizing suspense.
speaker: the lady

utterance: What was your son's name?
speaker: the boys

utterance: Why, that's our soldier!
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance:
Do you know him? Is-?
Is- -?
speaker: the lady

utterance: Yes'm. In our garden
speaker: the boys

utterance: Won't you come home with us? Our father and mother will be so glad to have you
speaker: the boys

utterance: Oh, yes, indeed. Certainly
speaker: the boys

utterance: We haven't got much. We didn't kill any squirrels this morning. Both our guns are broken and don't shoot very well, now.
speaker: the boys

utterance: Oh, yes, they're big folks
speaker: the driver

utterance: My son
speaker: the elder lady

utterance: I have one, too;-God alone knows where he is
speaker: the boys' mother

utterance: Come here, quickly!
speaker: the boys' father
